STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 16, 2023
Aprille Sutton
Child & Family Services of Northwestern Michigan
3785 Veterans DR,
Traverse City, MI, 49684
RE: License#: CB280201037
Dear Ms. Sutton:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 03/01/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Douglas Turrill, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB280201037
Licensee Group Organization: Child & Family Services of NW Michigan Inc
Licensee Designee: Aprille Sutton
Chief Administrator: Aprille Sutton
Name of Agency: Child & Family Services of Northwestern
Michi
Agency Address: 3785 VETERANS DR
TRAVERSE CITY, MI 49684-4516
Agency Telephone #: 2319468975
Original Issuance Date: 09/01/1990
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
a minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months
before being placed in foster care or a new physical
examination shall be completed within 30 calendar days
after being placed in foster care.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One of eight documented that the child was placed
on 10/21/22 and the Well Child was completed on 02/02/23, more than 30 days from
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
a minimum, include all of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One of eight reviewed documented that the child
was placed 06/17/22 and the dental exam occurred on 10/03/22, more 90 days from
placement.

Repeat Violation Established:
03/18/2022 Interim, CAP approved 04/14/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent Living Contract
2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The contract shall
be reviewed and updated at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
Two independent files were reviewed. One of two files did not document an updated
independent living contract.
CPA Rule 400.12708 Child evaluation.
(1) A social service worker shall complete a written
assessment of each child available for adoption within
60 days of the child being referred for adoption. The
assessment shall include all information available in
the foster care file from the date the child entered care
and shall meet all requirements of section 27 of 1939
PA 288, MCL 710.27.
Three adoption files were reviewed. One of three files documented that the child was
referred for adoption on 08/09/22, and the DHS 1927 was completed on 11/08/22, more
than 60 days from the referral for adoption.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have
been found to produce positive outcomes for children
in foster care. A quality visit is defined as one in which
the caseworker: • Can meet with each child
individually, without the presence of other
individuals, to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions as well as discuss the current placement. •
Views the child's bedroom and sleeping
arrangements. • Verifies safe sleep environments and
practices for infants under 12 months. • Assesses
each child’s educational, medical, dental, mental
health and other needs and takes appropriate action
or offers services in response to the identified needs
of each child. • Shows interest in the child to build and
establish rapport. • Shares and explains the case plan,
including the plan for parenting time, visits with
siblings and other relatives, and the child's
permanency plan, in a developmentally appropriate

way while allowing the child to ask questions and
express viewpoints. Private Meeting A private
meeting allows a caseworker to meet individually with
a child. The way a caseworker conducts a private
meeting will depend on the age and developmental
ability of the child.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two of eight files contained two contacts each that
lacked safety assessments and complete narratives. In one file the contacts occurred on
06/24/2022 and 09/27/2022. In a second file the contacts occurred on 05/25/2022 and
07/20/2022.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM. Updated Case Plan
(USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Eight foster care files and eighteen FTM’s were reviewed.
Four of eight files were missing one or more FTM’s.
Three of eighteen FTM’s reviewed contained documentation of the FTM occurring
however, the FTM’s were held more than 30 days from the report due date.
One of eighteen FTM’s reviewed lacked sufficient documentation.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
03/18/2022 Interim, CAP approved 04/14/2022.
03/9/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 04/05/2021.
FOM 722-08D Treatment plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who
are a member of a participating household. • Youth
ages 14 and older. • Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court ordered caregivers.
Eight foster care files and 22 PATP’s were reviewed. Five of 22 PATP’s reviewed
documented late signatures.
In one file a PATP dated October 11, 2022, was signed by the foster parent on February
15, 2022. This same file contained a PATP dated July 13, 2022, that was signed by the
foster parent on August 24, 2022, and signed by the parent on September 21, 2022.

A second file contained a PATP dated October 21, 2022, that was signed by the parent
on January 27, 2023.
A third file contained a PATP dated September 25, 2022, and the foster parent signed
the plan on January 26, 2023.
A fourth file contained a PATP Dated November 18, 2022, that the foster parent signed
on January 24, 2023.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
03/18/2022 Interim, CAP approved 04/14/2022.
03/9/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 04/05/2021.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
• Technical assistance was provided regarding youth with YAFC status who are
placed in an independent living placement. Discussion involved YAFC youth,
when in an independent living arrangement such as a college dorm or an
apartment, then that youth is considered to be in independent living and the
independent living rules apply. The independent living rules do not apply to
YAFC youth living with a relative, in a foster home or a CCI.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency initiated special evaluation #2023C0631016 on October 3, 2022, in
response to an allegation that the foster parent was using corporal punioshment on
relative foster children in her care. The agency confirmed that the foster parent was
employing corporal punishment on the children. An additional finding established
that the foster parent would dress up in a costume as a monster to threaten the 3
and 5 year children that she would eat them and lock them away. The agency
recommended revocation of the license.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency initiated special evaluation #2023C0631016 on October 3, 2022 in
response to an allegation that the foster parent was using corporal punioshment on
relative foster children in her care. The agency confirmed that the foster parent was
employing corporal punishment on the children. An additional finding established
that the foster parent would dress up in a costume as a monster to threaten the 3

and 5 year children that she would eat them and lock them away. The agency
recommended revocation of the license.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance:
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
The agency submitted an approved corrective action plan on April 14, 2022, in
response to violations established during the Interim Inspection completed on March
18, 2022. The agency CAP was successful in preventing repeat violations regarding
ten of the thirteen violations established in the inspection. The current renewal
inspection established three repeat violations.
The agency submitted an approved corrective action plan March 24, 2022, in
response to a violation established in special investigation #2022C0444007. The
agency CAP was successful in preventing a repeat violation of the rule.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators Assessment was reviewed and found to be thorough and
comprehensive. The assessment addressed the violations established in the
previous inspection and the CAP’s effectiveness in preventing additional violations.
The assessment named a number of barriers to the agency obtaining full compliance
as well as preventing repeat violations. Some of the barriers named included, but
are not limited to, loss of a FTM facilitator, a large 17 county service area, COVID,
and the new CWLM system.
Financial Overview
An agency financial audit dated September 30, 2022, conducted by an independent
certified public accountant was reviewed and indicates that the agency is current
with obtaining annual audits.
The agency submitted a copy of their annual budget for review and indicates the
agency is financially secure.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed reported that they feel they are a part of a supportive team and
that the team functions well. One staff member reported that the addition of male
staff has been good for the team. Team members report that they feel supported by
their supervisors and that they are knowledgeable in providing direction and overall
support. Team members report that they feel supported by their supervisors and that
their supervisors are knowledgeable in providing direction and overall support.
Description of Agency Walk Through

A walk though of the agency was conducted. There is sufficient office space as well
as visitation rooms for families. The agency is clean and nicely decorated. The
agency and workers are well equipped with appropriate technology needed to
perform the tasks required of their position.
VII. CPA ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst identified three safety alerts during her visits to the foster homes.
They are as follows:
Safety Alert # 1. On December 21, 2022, the CPA Analyst generated a safety alert
as the foster home was identified as being under construction including the
installation of new flooring. There are no children placed in the home. The CPA
Analyst informed the agency that a variance is needed until construction is
completed. The agency submitted a variance to DCWL on December 21,2022, noting
the construction and that no placements would occur until the work was completed.
The safety alert was resolved.
Safety Alert # 2. On December 21, 2022, the CPA Analyst generated a safety alert
regarding a report from the foster parent that a bedroom where the child sleeps may
have bed bugs. The agency was contacted and the foster parent was advised to use
a “bug bomb” in the bedroom which was accomplished on the evening of December
21, 2022 and confirmed by the foster care worker on December 22, 2022. There was
no further report of bed bugs. FIG funding would be sought for a professional
extermination company to treat the home for any infestation of insects, if indicated.
The safety alert was resolved on December 22, 2023. DCWL’s CPA Analyst followed
up with the agency on 03/16/2023 related to the bedbugs. The agency provided two
contacts documenting that there were no further issues with bedbugs in the home
(one from an in-home visit with the unlicensed relative foster parent and child at the
home on 02/21/2023, and one via phone confirmation with the foster parent on
03/16/2023).
Safety Alert # 3. On December 29, 2022, a safety alert was generated as the home
did not have a carbon monoxide detector. Additionally, it was reported by the foster
children that the relative parent was spanking the children. A safety plan was
generated by a DHHS Worker involved in the case and the agency generated an
additional safety plan on January 10, 2023. A photograph of an installed carbon
monoxide detector was provided to the agency and a signed safety plan by the
relative was also initiated. A delay is resolution of the safety alert occurred because
the relative was out of state on vacation. The safety alert was resolved on January
10, 2023.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.

March 10, 2023
_____________________________________
Douglas Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 16, 2023
